pullRequest.body:
This frees up the name `IsSemisimple` so that it can be used for the notion that matches the categorical concept.

In characteristic 0, this is equivalent to having a trivial radical.
In characteristic p > 0, there are counterexamples.

With this change, we depart from the terminology used by Seligman,
but we feel that the change is justified because we need a name for the categorical version of semisimplicity,
and the naming convention proposed in this PR is the "least surprising" one.

This PR also changes the definition of `LieModule.IsIrreducible` to exclude the trivial module.

---

Thanks for doing this!

Please feel free to merge once you've thought about the suggestions (and appeased `lake shake`).

bors d+

Given that you're here, maybe this whole definition could be replaced with:
```lean
/-- A Lie module is irreducible if its only Lie submodules are `⊥` and `⊤` (which may coincide). -/
abbrev LieModule.IsIrreducible (R L M : Type*) [CommRing R] [LieRing L] [LieAlgebra R L]
  [AddCommGroup M] [Module R M] [LieRingModule L M] [LieModule R L M] : Prop :=
  IsSimpleOrder (LieSubmodule R L M)
```

According to [rule 7](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html#general-conventions) the usual conventions apply to constructor fields too:
```suggestion
  sSup_isAtom_eq_top : sSup {I : LieIdeal R L | IsAtom I} = ⊤
```
(and similarly the other two fields)
The last field was already fine, no?

Optional: this should really be a pair of theorems:

-  the forward direction takes arguments `[HasTrivialRadical R L]` `I`,  `[IsLieAbelian I]` and proves `I = ⊥` (can probably be `simp`)
- the backward direction is an alternate constructor for `HasTrivialRadical`

Similarly for `hasTrivialRadical_iff_no_abelian_ideals` below

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Algebra/Lie): rename IsSemisimple to HasTrivialRadical
